Hi Bert,

> Hi Igor,
> 
> On Wed, 16 Jan 2008, 11:01, Igor Ranitovic wrote:
> 
>> In general, I strongly recommend to separate seeds from scope. In other
>> words, do not use seeds for scoping.
> 
> Could you, please, briefly explain why not?

There are several things that I don't like about it. It is limited to 
URI matching rules, can be confusing and forces you to teach people 
application specific rules. Heritrix automatic conversion of seeds to 
scope is limited to one to one mapping (one seed equals one URI matching 
scope rule) and the seeds conversion can result in unwanted scope.

To illustrate this we can use an example from Myspace. Let's assume that 
we have the seed bellow as part of a harvest collection that is related 
to Humor News:

http://www.myspace.com/onionnews

If we use this seed to define scope within Heritrix we can only achieve 
  host or domain scope. Both of these will expend the scope to 
non-related content. This seed requires scoping rules that can not be 
derived from the seed alone. We might need scoping rules on depth, 
priority, link type and custom rules specific to the site's content.


In general, scoping with seeds can be a good and clear shortcut. 
However, in long run the shortcuts usually prove to be the longest 
distances between two points :)


> 
>> This can be achieved by using scope directives either mixed with seeds 
>> or in a separate scope source. [...]
